FreeResponse: You need to have doctors qualified to do the procedure. I still dont think it would cut back on infections though.
Doctor should already know the procedure.
It is a proactive approach to helping patients. I think that is appropriate.
badges have nothing to do with deadly infections
Seems like a great idea. How could having a list of safety precautions be bad?
The doctors already have experience with the procedure so it would make it even more safe when they have exact directions
It sounds like a good idea. But I don't think it's going to be enough. More or better training is likely required.
Having them wear a list is appropriate, however i dont believe its the most effective way to lessen the amount of infections. Proper training would be an alternative.
I think it's appropriate to try this approach because it would be inexpensive and easy to do. I'm not sure it will be effective but it's still appropriate
It ensures that the doctor is reminded of the safety precautions. I don't see how this could be inappropriate

I chose very appropriate because the doctors that are given the safety procedures can be tracked. If something happens to a patient, it will be known which doctor did not follow the safety procedure. The safety precautions will work to reduce the number of incidents.

It as least gives some reassurance to the patients that the doctors have the badge and know how to do the operation as best as they can without giving infections. If they need a reminder they can refer to the badge for the steps needed.
The doctor wearing the badge doesn't make the procedure any less risky or guarantee that the doctor followed the instructions on the reverse of the badge.

Doctors should not have to be referencing the back of their ID badge to perform such a routine task. Inserting something into a vein should be a technique that is practiced and understood and if the doctor needs to be reminded of the protocol then he can read it beforehand. Should he/she carry the protocol for every medical procedure around with them all the time? That would be ridiculous, doctors should be trained and competent enough to not require a list of steps on the back of their ID badge for one specific procedure.
Placing a badge seems appropriate and helpful to the doctors. I see no downside to it.

I think it is a good idea that is worth a try, but I'm not sure it would make much difference since I'm not sure all doctors will pay attention to it. Some will find it sensible and some might find it insulting.
Anything that can reduce the risk of infection is beneficial to the patients
I would prefer to have a specifically trained doctor who was imminently aware of the risks and reminded of them with a ID badge perform the procedure on me or a family member.
It should help reduce infections.

Another instance of administration trying to cure a problem with paperwork. We see this in medicine all the time. It's part of the reason health care is getting more expensive. Just let us doctors do our jobs. If you want to post the procedure, put it ON THE WALL. Or, preferably, up the administrator's you know what.
I think it is appropriate because the doctor is potentially saving people from harm by adding safety precautions.
I choose the option because the director is trying to improve the safety of the procedure. I'm not sure if it is the most effective thing to do but at least he is making progress.
Its puts a lot more pressure on the doctors. This will make them less efficient and more prone to stress and anxiety.

It is a great reminder but more could be done to ensure patient safety. Along with new ID badges I would suggest a mentor/advisory group specificly for this procedure that is constantly reviewing journal updates and working together for best patient outcomes.
Because it is always a good idea to have doctors know standard safety procedures before attempting surgery. This is common sense.

It doesn't hurt anything, for one. Also, it ensures that if doctors are unsure of the precautions, they always have the instructions with them. The most important thing is to make sure people are safe and healthy, and this should help that.
It implies that the doctors are unfamiliar with the procedure. It would make the patients uncomfortable.
I think it's a good idea because it will remind doctors about the safety precautions and will hopefully lower the infection rate.
I don't know if it will make the dr look bad with this information on him/or her. I wouldnâ€™t want to know what the dr was doing if it were me getting it done.
I said somewhat inappropriate because to me it seems like they have to carry it around due to inability to remember. The medical professionals should be able to remember standard safety precautions.
I'm not sure. It just seems odd to know a doctor is relying on a cheat sheet to save my life.
Said hospital director is taking a "viable" approach--in making sure a doctor who may perform said procedure is well-versed and certified to do so in a safely manner.
Having a list of safety precautions could cut down on the amount of infections to the patients.
The more safety precautions against doctors making mistakes is a very good idea.
This will help to make sure that the proper safety precautions are taken, thus saving lives and preventing infection.
I believe that it is for the safety of patients and also to reduce liability of doctors.
Well it gives the docs an at hand guide if they forget something, and also no excuses if the doc foergets to do something and messes up.
There's nothing wrong with having a badge with safety precautions on your person. If it helps the patient and the doctor it can be beneficial

This is a very appropriate course of action because the safety of the patient is of paramount importance. It is the responsible thing to do to ensure that all precautions are being closely followed so that the life and health of the patient is not in any way compromised.
It reinforces the safety procedures and allows people to be more aware of the potential dangers. It will serve as a reminder for the doctors

It doesn't seem like an over reach or over bearing to have the list attached to the ID badge. My only concerns would be how common of a procedure is this and in turn I have my doubts as to the effectiveness of this measure.
These are professional who should be able to fight infections a lot easier than this
it cant hurt, so appropriate. but how can it really help, beyond appearance? so somewhat
Because experts can get so comfortable with what they are doing they will start to skip safety procedures. Also it is always nice to have a reminder.

This doesn't solve the problem. It only is a potential reminder to information the doctor MUST already be aware of. Plus the doctor would have to re-read the card in order for it to act as a reminder. Overall ineffective.
This ensures that the doctor knows the correct procedure and also has the procedure on them at all times.
It is a safety precaution that is easy to institute and although I would hope the doctors know this stuff by heart, it is better to be safe than sorry.
He wants to prevent infections from doctors mishandling equipment.

I chose somewhat appropriate because I thought it was a good idea that he had only the doctors with those tags being able to treat patients as it will cut down the number of infections. However, I think that to be truly effective the doctors should go through a quick retraining course and learn exactly how to do it to prevent any issues in the future.
It's a good idea to do something to remind doctors of the procedures, but just putting it on their badge may not get them to read or follow the procedures.
by having the badge it will serve as a reminder to take precautions that will reduce the risk of infections

I think it's an odd choice for a doctor to make. It's not directly related to the procedure, such as stopping infections, but it's a safety precaution checklist. It's a thing specialized professionals should already be doing, so it's hard for me to decide if its appropriate or not.
It's good to have a reminder of procedures and safety near by but patients may see this as a sign of incompetence.

something attached to the doctors badge will be hard for the doctor to see, while at the same time making the patient feel the doctor needs to be reminded of procedures, giving them less confidence in having the procedure done.

It is appropriate to have a reminder of the safety precautions nearby. However, doctors are highly trained individuals and infections can still happen despite all their training and precautions. While appropriate, it won't be an earth shattering sort of thing.

It is somewhat appropriate because it may help doctors be more precautious and follow procedures that could save lives. But on the other hand it seems like it should not be so difficult for a medical professional to just remember these kinds of things.
It might help the doctor to follow certain steps in case they forget to prevent infections.

It is good that the director is providing the information to the doctors, but without any actual training given, the patient gets a false sense of security that the doctor understands the precautions.

I think it's very inappropriate because they're treating doctors like children. Shouldn't a doctor have the protocol clearly in their mind - that is why they went to school for 8 years. They spent so much time studying complex topics - that memorizing the procedure should be a cake walk and they shouldn't need a cheat sheet.
Maybe their is a bad habit of forgetting the appropriate procedure so this is being implemented to see if infections decrease .
I think that the director's decision is very appropriate because he/she is ensuring that only doctors who understand the safety precautions for the procedure treat patients that need it.
gut feeling
What difference does it make whats on the badge. They wont read it even if they are ones giving the infections. Useless
It is appropriate because it's the easiest way to fix the problem or at least get closer to fixing it.
I think is a good reminder for the doctors and only doctors performing this procedures and then internally given access.
Infections need to be eliminated. No need to put someone under this type of risk!
The decision is a tough one, but the director's decision will minimize the infection and will save more lives.
It can never hurt to give people reminders.
I feel like it is neither appropriate nor inappropriate. It doesn't seem like something a doctor would actual look like, it seems like a weird place to put these precautions.

Because this list is pretty much irrelevant to the doctor's ability and/or the risk of getting infections just by chance. Its sort of, in a way, adding a red stop sign to a red stop sign. The doctor's should already know the list, they don't need another sign or list explaining this to them.
this is a nosy doctor. all coming up with a "good idea" and everyone's all rolling their eyse
I think it is appropriate for the director to implement this safety precaution because it will likely reduce the number of infections that result from a mistreatment.
I believe that this would be somewhat appropriate because it would remind Dr. of the procedures but it would also scare patients because it may make patients believe that the dr is not capable.
I chose somewhat appropriate because hopefully the doctor will look at it and go over the safety precautions often. I am not sure the doctor will even look at it.
All the procedures that are for safety can't be ignored. whether this helps for not is to be seen however its not too much to give it a try.
Everything, including every procedure, should be documented. Leave no stone unturned, period.
It sounds like a measure to help the doctors and to protect patients. It might be a little embarrassing for the doctors, but overall it is in the patient's best interests.
It will help the doctor remember safety precautions. It will also provide patients with a sense of comfort knowing the doctor is wearing the badge.

I believe that what the doctor is doing by making infections more scarce is a step in the right direction. There will always be that case where nothing was able to be done and something causes infection, but Im glad that this doctor is trying to do his best.

I think it's completely appropriate to have a checklist handy of steps to help prevent infections, I think it would help cut down on infections if both the doctor and the patient know what the proper procedure is.
The decision is appropriate if there is a good chance of it working.
I don't think it would really make a big difference. Doctors know all of that information already.
It seems reasonable. It could help people.
II think that is a good idea but not sure a sick person would realize weather or not he/she is being treated by the badged person or not
We can identify the doctors who does that operation easily by this decision
He isn't informing patients on the deadly infection risk
I think it's appropriate because it will probably make patients more aware of the risks of the procedure.
It helps keep infection to a minimum if only the doctors who have been trained in the safety precautions. This way, the less experienced doctors will not be able to treat those who need the tube.
It marks the doctors who are the most experienced at this task to perform it regularly.
I think it's important for the patient to understand the procedure.
It could help the patients feel more trusting of their doctor's abilities, & doctors are humans too, so they could use reminders that are close by just in case

I think this is a very good idea because no person ever wants someone who they are not sure has been well trained inserting something into a major vein. Also if they are not awake at the time it would make the decision easier for their family.
Since this is something new and probably not well tested it would be required that precautions are taken. And in the even treatment is needed the list will be readily available which is a good thing.
It is smart to know who can do this function
It may signal to other people what disease they have, raising privacy concerns.
The Id is a form my identification. I would not want to random person sticking a tube in me. This way the patient knows exactly who s doing what.
I chose somewhat appropriate because there is nothing wrong with this action, but I'm not sure that it would be very effective.
I think research like this is necessary to determine what is more effective.

The setup might be OK, but a better way would be to run a test that doesn't have a consequnce to see which one makes you follow instructions better. This one is on the border of ethics, as you are not purposefully denying or infecting any patients.
It is inappropriate to treat people in this manner, rather than treating them the appropriate way. They should not be subject to a guessing game experiment in regards to their health.
The patients weren't informed they were part of an experiment. No procedural outline was distributed to participating physicians.
it felt like the right thing to say
If the doctor is not careful, no reminder will help him
having a controlled test is often the only way to see what works.
As long as the doctors read the precautions either on the badge or poster, I think the director made an appropriate decision. Using the procedure that has the highest survival rate is also good.

Well initially I thought this was appropriate in terms of validating a scientific study. But this isn't really an experiment. If in this case you know one options works better then the other, then make both the standard. That way all doctors will get message, for the mere cost of a few more badges or posters. This was a hospital bean counter trying to save a few bucks at the expense of people's lives and is ultimately very inappropriate, all while billing patients $10 for a damn aspirin.
I understand the idea behind it in that you want to know which is best, but this is inappropriate. People's lives are at stake, therefore no experiment should be done, we need to save lives.
It just feels like Russian roulette. There has to be a better way to notify of the precautions that will guarantee the best way to do this.
It seems a little sketchy to test things on actual human patients but this is also not that risk of a test. I'm kind of in the middle about it.
It's a good experiment and follows all of the regular rules, I just don't know how ethical it would be to base a decision after 1 year.

You are putting people's lives at risk by using them as experimental subjects when they could get a deadly infection as a result. While I am not a specialist in creating experiments, there must be some other way to reduce these infections. How about antibiotics?
I don't think that it's appropriate to treat humans as lab rats. Though experiments are risky this seems way more risky than normal.

Since both doctors are aware of the safety precautions, I don't think it's a terrible idea. But to play around with survival rate of patients seems like something that shouldn't be played around with.
The procedures are being performed regardless of the risk. This only looks to improve upon that risk.
If the patients are going to be in the study then they should be informed of the possibility of having either procedure
It's a unique way to test out these infections, I am interested in this way of doing things.
If he is sure one or the other would save lives, why not do both? It seems a feasible solution. Why risk more lives?
I guess he wants to see what works best, so going forward, they can do a better job.
It sounds like they are conducting an experiment with humans. It seems like they have no value for human life.
Safety precautions are listed in both conditions. This can help determine which way is better.
Both options intend to reduce infections, with little chance of causing additional harm. Without knowing which will provide better results, there is no cause to prefer one over the other.

I think that it's tough because it can be a life or death thing, but if there is no information or research up front, you need to start somehow. This is probably borderline inappropriate, because for something this serious, you'll probably need to do a bit more research and then pivot towards whichever way has the highest survival rate.

It seems inappropriate to be doing a test like this using patients whose actual health is on the line. It's not a huge deal, I guess, the instructions being printed in different places, but maybe if they were testing on patients where mistakes could lead to deadly infections it wouldn't feel so bad.
Need more information. Who approved this experiment. Where is the documentation for it. Where the patients notified of this and do they have a choice to opt out of it.
I think they are just risking peoples lives. It would be best to just provide everyone with the proper instructions.

Care and precaution is used in both instances, and there's no consensus on which method of showing the safety precautions is better. Patients wouldn't mind if the doctor had the measures on a badge or in plain site on a poster.

His intentions are good, because his overall goal is to reduce infections. However, this kind of test might be better conducted on non-human subjects. Even though in both cases, the info is available for the doctors on correct procedures, if the study results in one group actually surviving better than the other, then that means that the study put the less-surviving group's lives at an unnecessary risk.

Deciding to treat based off this particular experiment is inappropriate. You have to account for skill levels of the providers in this case and you have to make sure the providers are adequately trained. Treating a patient should be based on evidence supporting that particular treatment. But one study suggesting treatment is better because of arbitrary outcomes as listed here wouldn't be good for the patients.
Either way gives the necessary information about the chance of infection. The method with the highest survival rate will be the method used to give out this info.
i think this is a smart way to do it

I think the test is not a very safe way to conduct the experiment. They should not be using real live patients to try and figure out the best way to treat them. The way it is setup can harm people and effect them in the real world.
This option was a good one for the doctor because the processes he chose did not create any greater risk for the patients than they would normally be subjected to.
the patients did not know that they were part of an experimental study, so this will be unethical
It doesnt increase the risk for anyone and has a chance of reducing the risk for future patients.
I'm not sure about using people who are sick to test something like this. I do think it's worth knowing which is safer though.
There is no need to have the two groups. You just post the in instructions in a highly visible location so everyone can follow the recommendations.

I am unsure. I don't know how I feel about the manipulation, or the not letting patients really "know" what is going on. I don't think it is fair to "gamble" with someones life. Its a bit scary to me.
It would seem that all doctors had access to the same information. This should not have imoacted anyone in a negative way.
The director is doing this without the consent of the patients. Doing that is illegal and immoral. If the patients consented themselves to this it would be fine.

I am lead to believe the infections only happen when the doctors make mistakes, so I suppose I can think of no other way to determine what method of teaching the doctors leads them to kill the fewest people.
If it works and there is no problems then go on ahead and do it. If there is no major consiquences then do it.
Until they know what is more effective, he is giving both options a chance. They are not prohibiting the patients from being healed in any way.
Playing with lives that way isn't something that people should do. It should be the norm to apply both in order to increase the survival rate of every patient.

All the standard safety precautions are being followed in both sets so there is no risk to patients. The quality of the patients treatment is not affected by this test, so there is no real reason to think that this is a bad idea.
People should not be used in experiments without their knowledge.
He's being pro active on solving a problem and is open to several ideas. Although it feels like he's experimenting on patients.
You're risking people's health over using a badge or poster.
Humans cannot be used in experiments without their consent. Especially when great harm is possible.

Science is only possible when hypotheses (in this case, a new method) are tried and either proved or disproved. It can be assumed that neither of the options the director chose are worse than what is being done currently. It is correct to determine which new method is superior to avoid choosing one option and then later finding out that it wasn;t best. I selected only somewhat appropriate though because there should be a control group of people treated using the current method only to make sure that the new methods are actually effective.
Well someone has to make the final decision. I think the director would be a appropriate person for the task.
R_aWfuAxtruQsK2qJ

A year seems a long time where the patients are guinea pigs. It seems like more thought should be given as to which would work best instead of using a year's worth of data. What would it hurt to just implement both policies?

I think it's unethical to use humans in an experiment like this. Certainly the director may be able to gleam information, but it will be at the cost of human lives. There are other ways to figure out which method is better without sacrificing human lives.

I think it is clear that being treated by the doctors who are constantly reminded of the process will make for healthier patients. The doctors relying on using the wall poster will be distracted if they are trying to complete the process and will not have the information on their person's at all times.

With either method, the doctors have the precautions listed for them. Either way, it would be up to the doctor to remember to actually look at the list, so where they have to look to see it wouldn't make much of a difference.
The only way to get an accurate result is to have a control group.
Because the other group needs SOME safety standards. You can't willingly subject a group to see what happens.

Since people sometimes get deadly infections because of this treatment, it would make sense to find out a way to prevent that. Not knowing the best way to prevent this from happening, it would make sense to monitor if a certain condition could affect this outcome. The doctor isn't intentionally hurting his patients, but looking at what scenario helps his patients the most.
They are treating the patients relatively the same way, just with different safety precautions listed in a different place. They will be able to determine what works best with this test.
It'd be more appropriate to just do both.
I don't think its fair to the patience. They don't even get to choose what they want.

This is how you are going to prevent infections? Maybe I don't understand but shouldn't your doctor know what he is doing without a list of instructions in any form? When I had back surgery, was the doctor watching a "how to" video on youtube or did his knowledge and experience guide him through. Again, maybe I don't understand, but why do they need instructions?

Both of those ideas are good, but ideally you shouldn't be doing science with things that can save lives, you should be immediately going right to the life-saving, if there's no downside to either of them, they should have just done both immediately.
I believe that all the people involved should know about precautions
Patients did not have consent in the experiment, could lead to deaths
The director is trying to see which method will reduce infection. The doctors will still have access to the same information.
Good to test things but having a doctor touch their id badge during working hours is may increase the spread of infections. Better to have a study simply with and with out posters.

I don't think that this experiment should be tested on humans. The director knows the risk and there is a high possibility that quite a few people could die. I think that this experiment should be tested on animals.
Testing both options in such a manner is fine. There should be a control group as well though so they can see if either actually make any improvement at all.
Because it tests on people
Only way to find the truth. Either will probably be an improvement over doing nothing anyway.
the id badge is a much better method. a poster can become compromised and critical life saving information could be missed.
The patients in the study have no idea they are being used as test subjects which seems to me unethical. The doctor should have the other doctors be well prepared before treating the patients.
The director is trying to stop as many infections as possible which is a good thing but doesn't know how to accomplish it so has chosen to experiment with different tactics.
It's somewhat inappropriate if the doctor does not inform the patients of this procedure. There will have to volunteers.
I believe that the choice should be the patients, not assigned randomly.
I understand the need for the study, but it is unethical to do so without the consent of patients.
Both set of patients will be treated by doctors trained in current safety precautions. It will be valuable to find out which set of reminders leads to the highest survival rate.

It seems to basically be flipping a coin as to what will be the outcome. Other factors at play will influence how much the infections can be reduced. For something this serious, a more scientific effort should be made instead of just how the doctor can view the information.
It seems like a reasonable idea, that is both low cost and doesn't appear to have any downside. With no real possibility for harm to patients there is no reason not to test the director's idea.
It seems like a fair and reasonable way to determine which method works the best. It wouldn't endanger anyone, since both things will be an improvement on the previous method.

I think simply running an experiment on something that is dealing with life or death in such a casual way or decision is somewhat inappropriate. I wouldn't put it was very inappropriate but we are talking about peoples lives and infections. I think through only options we can see the best way to reduce infections without risking patients who are put under this experiment, simply looking a year later at survival rates to see which one is better sort of puts one side towards failure, which is going to bring along more deaths.
It's wrong to play with people's lives, but there must be a way to find out wich method is better.
I think it should be patient's choice, not a blind game.
The patient should always be made aware of the consequences of a procedure. Compromising this information for the sake of research seems unethical.
I think it is better to list the precautions by hanging them on the wall. To have them listed on the back of a badge where patients cannot see them and are unaware is wrong.

While I don't disagree with using two different methods to find the one that makes it easier for patients to understand the procedure, the criteria for how it turns out are far too extreme. The doctors should ask the patients before the procedure if they fully understand, and then judge the two methods by who did and didn't understand before the procedure.

The same guidelines will be given in both scenarios. It's an experiment to determine which method of delivering the guidelines is more effective, therefore I don't see it as compromising the level of care that should be expected in either scenario.
I mean it seems like it was thought out well enough. But with only 1 paragraph of information I really don't have much more to say.
As long as there is adequate training in the first place then I see nothing ethically wrong with trying this. It would not put anyone at undue risk and may help save lives in the future.
I think the patients should get the same treatment
Good idea to find out which way is more appropriate.

I feel that as a director, this person should take more responsibility for the liability of the hospital. Also, this person should be ensuring the safety of all patients and employees, therefore, this decision should be made prior to real-life practice.
I think it would be inappropriate because he is doing an experiment without patient consent which can lead to an infection in some of the patients.
If there's a way to reduce infection then everyone should be following that protocol, not putting innocent lives at risk to do an experiment.
I don't think it matters where they are printed
I think it won't matter as doctors are smart and will remember regardless of the signs. It won't matter.

Neither of these options will prevent or reduce infection. Just because you tell people what the safety standards are, if they don't follow it, it's pointless. People need training not I'd badges and posters.
I think its innovative to try to see what is going to work best. Obviously has patients care at heart.
Good way to determine the best course to present the information.
I don't believe in human testing
How is the doctor to see the safety precautions if they are on his shirt? I would trust the doctor more who had the precautions on the wall beside him where he can view them.
Sometimes it is necessary to try methods to discover better ways of doing things
I think he has the right idea, but they would do this experiment in a different situation where lives are not at risk.
This will allow them to determine which is more effective.
The decision is not inappropriate, but will not reduce infections. A better procedure would be to require the doctor to complete a checklist.
He's using these unwilling people in an experiment to see which is more effective.

The doctor is trying a new method to cut down on the infection. Both options include the same procedures with the same precautions. The only difference is where the precautions are printed. Patients are used without their knowledge all the time. This is neither right nor wrong, its reality.

This is very unnecessary. I cannot see how this will help the patients in any way. The doctors area already knowledgeable about the procedure (at least they should be at this point) and they don't need this extra stress added to them.
To see the differencr between the group
i would need more

I just don't understand how where the safety precautions are printed is relevant to the procedure or the well-being of the patient. To test his ideas he should have one group of patients be tested with his first idea to reduce infection and another group be tested with his second idea to reduce infection.
Each patient should be treated equally
I would think a doctor should have either adequate knowledge or training of proper safety precautions and they should have the sole responsibility of advising patients of the risk.
I guess he feels alot of infections are cause due to lack of correct procedures. Some people are more successful with instructions in their face.
I think it's fine. It gives the same info but the info is in a different location. I think the poster might be more noticeable though.
He's making an active decision to see what works and it doesn't directly effect the patient health because they're still at the same risk of infection.
I believe both ways can be effective. At this point there's no way to know until afterwards to see which one is better
Anything would help the understanding of this deadly infections so they can be stop or control is a good thing
I think that the patient may be at risk by this experiment, which is why I chose this option.
I feel ike the director shouldn't be experimenting with anyone's health. If they know both of these options work, provide both from the get go!
I don't feel that changing where the information is made available will change the outcome of the number of being getting an infection.
I think they have access to the same information

I think it is inappropriate for the patients to be unwitting subjects to this experiment. While I don't see any particular problem with the experiment, the patients should be informed what is going on.
Because youre putting half of the people at risk of something they wouldn't get otherwise.
I think that this decision will work as long as every dr knows what they are doing.
Doctors should pay attention to all rules whether they are posted or on the ID badge so I don't really see the difference
he's not really doing anything to harm others, but he's not really doing much to promote standard procedures. i guess this is a blind test, but it doesn't really seem all that scientific.
He should not be running an experiment, as this is potentially dangerous. If it goes wrong, he could lead to people dying.
If there is a pretty clear way to reduce infections, particularly in such a serious issue, it should be unethical to deny such treatment/practices to patients.
There is no control group
He shouldn't be testing on random patients.

I'm assuming the procedures Are Instructions for the doctor. So unless the patients have been informed, it seems unethical to perform this experiment. If the patients agree to. It then there shouldn't be a problem.
Both scenarios could lead to the doctor being more aware of the safety precautions. The doctor can easily access it on his ID Badge for the one group and the other can easily see it on the wall.
Because either way they have access to the information immediately.

He did not get the express permission of the people/patients involved to do this "Experiment" to see which precautions would work better I think. Perhaps there's another way to test if the poster or print on back method is better, that would NOT involve risk of infection of death.
not controlled study - but interesting to find out results if patients know what to be ware of.
It's a dangerous way to test his experiment. You can't experiment with people's lives.
Neither method is proven. It is highly likely that those with procedure on a badge never look at it.

It seems unfair to the patients to assign them randomly when such serious side effects could be involved, but both groups are being treated by doctors who have access to the safety precautions. I don't think how those precautions are accessed makes much difference.

There should be a standard set of procedures for both groups and they should be aware of the dangers of what they are doing and have it be understood by them. The half of the patients who get the doctor with the ID card might not like that and would rather be in the group with the precautions on the wall so they could read it themselves and vise versa. It would be inappropriate to have two sets of standard for different people.
I feel like if that is what they need to do then that is what it is. When there is so many people you have to make choices.
It is very inappropriate because this is essentially human experimentation. This should be done under non-dangerous lab conditions rather than in the field.

I think that people could rush through things and become lazy, having a poster would be a reminder of all that is to be done. I think the poster is the best idea, as it is a reminder for everyone. I think it would be easy for a Dr. to not bother looking at the back of his ID badge for a refresher, plus that might make a patient lose confidence in him, this is why I chose "somewhat appropriate", I don't think the ID badge is the best place to list the precautions.
Running a test on someone without their consent isn't okay, even if nobody is getting worse care than they originally did.
As long as the procedures gets displayed and they are not putting more difficulty in themselves, it would be appropriate, the experiment seems fair with the random method implied.
Great way to find out what works best or if there's any difference.
It subjects non consenting patients to tests that could put their health in serious danger.
I am not sure. It might save lives.
I think as long as the doctor isn't doing anything to intentionally harm his patients, it's fine. I would also think the patients know what they're getting themselves into.
The ID badges could be contaminated as they go into different wards of the hospital.
The story doesn't mention anything about the patients giving consent to the experiment.
The director's decision is supposed to be about how to reduce the infections. Not sure where the safety precautions are locate has to do with the process.

There is not really enough information to determine the appropriateness. Have the doctors gone through any training prior to this experiment, does the badge remove easily for reference, how big is the poster?

I don't know how comfortable I am with this director using patients in potentially life-threatening situations as fodder for an experiment. I'm also not sure what he's trying to accomplish with said experiment.
It is appropriate because the director is trying to reduce infections by reminding people who are already trained in precautions by experimenting on which - if either would be effective.

At first I thought this would put patients at greater risk of infection if they got a doctor that didn't check the precautions on the wall or on the ID, or if one is less effective. However a patient would be at risk of that anyway if their doctor didn't know the precautions or bother checking them.
The precautions are listed but not everyone will look at the doctors id badge
The doctor doesn't seem to be taking any risks. His/Her experiment could potentially offer insight that would help future patients.
Seems like a reasonable precaution to ensure that doctors follow the safety procedures. But they need to take into account how thorough and knowledgeable the doctors were to begin with.
All involved have access to the same information. There is no danger to the patient.
I don't think any of the conditions will change the outcome.

Assuming that the Doctor's are already highly trained in how to prevent infection, this is an appropriate way of testing which method, if either, would better help remind the Doctor's of the safety precautions.
I think it's slightly innapropiate to makes experiments at patient's expense.

A doctor should already know the precautions but it certainly doesn't hurt to have them available during the procedure. It would be unethical to have one group assigned to a doctor that hadn't been trained in the precautions or something like that. But this is just a way to try to see if having the precautions as a poster or on a badge will help more. Nothing about this is directly putting patient's in harm's way.
I chose this option because I really wasn't sure whether or not the project was a good idea.
this doesn't seem like a good idea to have half the people treated by someone not as up to speed with latest precautions.
The patients' decisions of whether or not they want to participate in these experiments is not part of the equation.

I would not want the procedures for a form of treatment that I am about undergo to be posted on a wall where I can read them. I don't mind for them to be told to me, but I don't want them where I can read them.

There was no informed consent obtained by the patients, or mention of this study being approved by an IRB. Patients have the right to choose to be a part of a study, even if they do not know which group/panel they will be in.
He is still risking one group's safety with the experiment. As a hospital director, this should not be something he tries himself and she be done by scientists and researchers instead.
Hospitals should not experiment on their patients. Research should b conducted via studies with willing participants.

I think it's appropriate because the conditions of the test are varied enough to give good data. It's not a terrible risk for patients since the infections are already occurring and this might give an insight into how best to minimize this.
I think it is important to do studies like this on the population. This is the only way to test in real world situations what method is better for informing patients about aftercare.
A hospital should not perform experiments on unknowing patients. Patients should have the rights to completely understand the situation so they can decide themselves.
There is no control group.
I think it is inappropriate because he's experimenting on people's health and life. There is no mention of whether the patients have given their consent for the experiment.
it doesn't seem right that patients would be randomly assigned. i feel they should have a choice in their own treatment.
I think it's a good idea to have a poster listing the precautions on the wall, to warn patients. I would like all patients to get a understanding of the risks though, verbally most preferably.
I feel it's somewhat inappropriate because the people just looking at the poster won't have access to the same care as everyone else.
Every patient is entitled to exactly the same rights to view the safety precautions, especially because it could be deadly. The patient should decide if they want to risk death.
This seems to be testing a placebo effect, where if the patient knows there is a possible risk of infection, the overall number of infections may rise.
I think that's somewhat appropriate because patients receiving the treatment should have access to the precautions. Patients should have full information as far as what's happening to them.
he is basically treating people like lab rats which is not fair at all.Instead of showing people the safety measures he just gives one a poster while the others get a doctor.
I think it will be an interesting experiment. It will show whether having the precautions readily at hand on the badge will sway a doctor's decision to perform the procedure.
It helps patients be more aware of the procedures that will take place. This will ensure that they understand what will be done.

I think the poster is the only logical option in this situation because the patients who see the doctor with the ID badge may not receive the necessary information, whereas the poster group will see it almost immediately upon checking into their room.
I've had picc lines and mid lines before and I know all the risks. I think it is important to educate people about the risks and the director is trying to figure out the best way to do this.
It's a simple solution that makes doctors more cognizant of conseq of their actions
The posters would serve as a reminder/check list for medical staff and the patient can be proactive in their care by paying attention to whether or not the procedures were followed.
It's very appropriate because this will remind the doctors of the safety precautions. This will also show the patients that the doctors take safety very seriously.
I don't want to think about what could go wrong moments before I have to have it done. It's last minute and would make me fearful.
I think it's important for the doctor to be constantly reminded of safe practices, along with the patient to be aware of the safe practices to know when to speak up if they are not being followed.
A reminder is beneficial to the staff and informative for the patient.
If there is not a better way of doing this procedure, then I think it will help for all staff to have reminders on the wall of how to do it in the most safe way possible.
Seems like a good thing to do. SHows what needs to be done
The number of infections will be reduced so it is appropriate.

Because if a patient saw that they could get anxious and wonder why it's there. Are the doctors not trained enough to complete the procedure without additional guidance? At the same time, you can't realistically expect all people to be able to retain all information they ever learn. It seems somewhat reasonable that the doctors have a guide just in case, and it could definitely prevent infections if they have a list readily available.

There are always risks of infections and problems after medical procedures, and showing them to others in the room can both show what may happen if an issue should occur. It may also have negative effects, like increased stress and worrying during or before a procedure if this is shown to the patient.
I think it might reduce infections and is a good reminder to all.
I think it is a very proactive step. It seems very logical.
The hospital director is taking a step in trying to reduce deadly infections. The posted list serves as a reminder to the people of precautions to take which is not a bad thing.
That is scary that you can get a deadly infection from this.
Its appropriate because the poster will help people remember how to avoid infection.
It'll help make sure no steps get forgotten by the people doing the procedure

The decision sounds like a very wise one, and one that will help to prevent infections. If this doctor has an idea like this that is intended to help to remind medical personnel to use proper procedures which will help to reduce infections which may lead to death, why wouldn't it be a good idea and very appropriate?
This is completely reasonable. If it leads to less infections and only requires specific rooms and a list of safety precautions it is a very wise decision.

I don't think it does any harm and having the poster in every procedure room means that the doctors performing the procedure will certainly remember the guidelines and have absolutely no excuse for not following them.
I think it is helpful because even though there's "common sense" with safety precautions. There still should be a list to help out surgeons anyway.
People will stop getting treatment all together. They will be nervous about the procedures they might need.
I think it will add to the patient's discomfort and worry.
I think that it would be very helpful to have a poster that lists the standard safety procedures. I think it would help stave off infections and inappropriate procedures.
It helps the doctor complete there job.
this is appropriate, because it would reduce infections
It seems that it would make those performing the procedure more accountable.
People should be informed of risks and what the staff should be doing to avoid issues.
It is good because it will remind any performing the procedure to follow the guidelines.
I think it is neither because it is most likely to be ineffective. Also, it should be targeted to those doing the procedure specifically.
THERE IS NOTHING WRONG WITH WORK REMINDERS ESPECIALLY WITH MEDICAL TREATMENTS LIKE THIS. AS LONG AS IT IS NOT VISUAL TO PATIENTS IT IS OK IMO.

This is important so patients know they are being treated by a standard that will reduce the possibility of them receiving an infection. It also shows the hospitals commitment to keep patients safe and reducing the amount of infections to as low as possible.
If they know what to look out for and how to treat it they are better off so they dont get a infection.
This makes perfect sense. A reminder will not hurt anyone and has the potential to help save lives. He could have gone even further and put it in every room in the hospital, but this is a good step.
This form of lateral encouragement to be safe is very effective. The poster reinforces the proper procedure and confirms its high priority.
The procedure will always be risky. However, the doctor is taking the necessary precautions to help make the procedure safer across the board.
I think anything that can help save lives and prevent infection is good. The director just seemed to be proactive in how he approached the situation.
It seems like something worth trying, and won't hurt, but I am skeptical that it will make a real difference.
It seems like this may be a reminder to doctors of what the correct procedure is and may help the problem. It may also provide more information to patients.
I chose this option because I think hanging the posters in the rooms benefits the doctors. The procedure itself is one that needs reminding that it can be dangerous if not performed correctly.
It reminds all individuals on how to take necessarily precautions to prevent infections.
It's something that might be required for a procedure.
It is the right thing to do to let everyone know what all the risks are for this medical procedure. I like this idea.
There is no risk and only benefit to doing the above action. It is a non intrusive way to remind doctors and patients that the procedure can result in problems if safety precautions are not taken.
I thinj the patients have the right to know about the correct protocol for their procedure. It may also help remind the health care providers to be more dilife nt and can remind them.
It couldn't hurt. I'm not entirely convinced it's necessary, though.
The posters are a reminder of the safety precautions needed in order to safely perform the procedure. I would feel better as a patient knowing these reminders are around.
I mean it's like putting 'Must Wash Hands Before Returning To Work' in the bathroom of a commercial restaurant.
It's a good step towards preventing these infections but I think there are better ways to do things and more to be done.
It gives Doctor's a reference while they do the procedure. That quick memory refresher may save thousands of lives.

I believe that there is some inappropriateness to this, in the sense that it can be seen as rude and passive aggressive. However, it is being done to reduce the rate of infection (and therefore potential death), so the benefits far outweigh the potential downsides. So while it might be socially inappropriate to a degree, it would arguably be more inappropriate to refrain from doing that, since the safety of the patient is the most important thing.
Just in case the doctor is doing something he shouldn't be the patient can stop him. Everyone needs to be refreshed on what to do from time to time.
It makes patients more aware of risks and how to prevent the risk of infection. They can pay attention to staff to make sure that they are following proper protocol.
this serves as a reminder to all personnel. there are certain procedures that maximize success.
There should be other viable methods of doing this procedure without the side effects.
This perhaps would lead to less infections because safety procedures would be followed. The patient might also be more aware of the risks.

The doctor is trying to help reduce infections, so his intentions are good. I am not sure how appropriate the posters are as I have no idea what they look like or what words or pictures are on them. I chose somewhat appropriate because I can't make an informed decision without seeing the poster first.
It might remind the doctor of the safety precaution to prevent infections but some might ignore it.
Hanging a poster on the wall doesn't make a room, or the equipment used in it, more sterile, and it is no substitute for an ongoing program of training, awareness and improvement.
IVs are common place in hospitals and it is important to reinforce safety precautions for this procedure. I think it would be very appropriate to have a poster on the wall for procedure rooms.
I chose this one because I think it will be better to reassure the patients he knows what he's doing.
This is a good reminder to let people know about the risks. Its forward thinking and an excellent reminder
it's good to have procedures posted to do good work

I think the workers doing the procedure would benefit from a constant reminder of the correct way to do it. By seeing the example on the wall, they will always have it in their mind that they need to do it the right way.

It is a potentially dangerous procedure, so no precaution would be too great to save lives and money for the hospital. It would be good to have the poster in the rooms, so that medical personnel remember to show care each time they perform the procedure.

It is the doctor's responsibility to ensure staff know how to properly perform the procedure in order to reduce disease and infection. The doctor has discretion in determining how to reduce disease and unless his action will cause harm in another way then it should be followed. Hanging a poster makes staff members performing the procedure more aware, but doesn't cause harm, so it is very appropriate.
It is a nice gesture to cut down on infections. I don't see any problem with it.
its an appropriate step. there could be better ones but it is a good one. seeing constant reminders of procedure is always good.
It is a way to help infrections and acts as a reminder for medical personal
It would be alarming for a patient to see warnings about how dangerous her upcoming procedure was.
As a director, he is ensuring that his employees follow the proper procedures and giving customers full knowledge of the possibility of infection.
I think it's good for patient and caregiver it will make the doctor be more careful and also make the patient more aware if doctor is following procedure.
Patients and providers should be educated on the proper procedures. It may help the providers to be reminded by the posters.
Since it is in good intention to help people not get infections.
This is because any measure that makes it less possible for these infections is very appropriate.
It serves as a reminder to those administering the tubes. It may not be the most effective method, but it wouldn't hurt.

The hospital director wants to inform patients about the possible side effects of inserting a plastic tube into a large vein. This should lead to a patient better understanding of the risks and rewards for this treatment.
Patients and providers should be made aware of all pertinent safety precautions of procedures they are undergoing. It is the responsible and ethical thing to do.
i think any ideas to tell more people of the deadly infections is a good thing.
I think patients should know the risks. The only downfall is they might be more anxious with knowing as well, but they need to know so they can be aware.
I think it's fair for patients to understand the risks of the procedure. This may lead to them making poor choices about having the tube inserted, but that is their choice.

I don't think hospitals should be relying on posters to inform patients about safety precautions they should be taking. If it is that important for the patients to know this information, then make them read about it and sign it to confirm that they have. It would probably be even better to have the doctor or a nurse explain this information to a patient and they can judge whether the patient was paying attention/understood it. A poster doesn't seem to be doing enough in my estimation.

I feel people should know the risks but I also feel some will be more scared of the risks versus the possible outcome of not receiving this life saving procedure. This might scare patients and they may refuse treatment that could save them . People don't always realize what is best for them.
It's always right to let people know the risks.
I think the doctor should explain the risks involved, but it's good to have it up as a secondary way for patients to understand the risks. You can't have too much knowledge.
It is what it is
I picked very appropriate because a patient should be informed of any and all risks that are involved with any procedure and the director is right to inform them.
I would like to know what procedures should be followed to keep me safe. The posters would give me the chance to make sure that procedures are followed.
It doesn't hurt to have additional information on safety precautions. Hopefully by putting patients in these rooms, they will better understand the risks and procedures that they should follow.
Patients have the right to be as safe as possible. They should know what safety procedures will be used.
I think patients have a right to know the effects of what may happen to them during procedures and what is being placed into their bodies during medical procdures.
However, the only real argument against it is that the director might consider the problem solved and ignore future cases of infections. But that's a stretch.
I think it is informative. I think it would help patients make an informed choice.
A reminder of safety procedures is always appropriate. Hopefully, the professionals doing the job will read the poster.
It is best to spread the word and keep the patients informed as to exactly what the risks are. It's likely a person would notice a poster regarding their procedure while they wait to be seen.
I think measures like this, do no harm and help remind medical professionals of important steps and of the dangers that can happen.

Even though it could be argued in court that the doctor was free of liability since this information was in view to patient, it would be only reasonable to personally address the risks with the patient before every procedure.

It makes sense to warn people about the dangers if they don't follow basic precautions about the procedure. It makes more sense to have them clearly visible in the room it'll be done in where the doctor can go over it with them.
It would be altogether easy just to do both, so why do only one?
Well, at least he is making gains to fix it.  He did identify the problem.
I think it would be a good resource for a new doctors, but it would concern me if an established doctor had to look at the list. I feel that he or she should already know what they are doing.
It will allow him to figure out which way works best for the doctors.  Although, I think the doctors shouldn't need a reminder of the correct steps to take.
I think formal education would help more than these two methods.
It can help people
I don't really feel one way or another about the situation and can see both benefits and negatives.
Because it will add an extra layer of security to the procedure. It will remind workers of the steps that need to be taken to prevent infection.
Seems fair to me.
its not a study if there is no control group
I think it would bring peace of mind to the patients, but it does not guarantee that the Doctor who would be performing the procedure is confident or knowledgeable.

all safety precautions should be in plain sight.
all patients should be able to decide which option they want

I think the poster will serve as a reminder as to the importance of using all safety precautions to minimize the risk of infection to the patient. I don't think the poster is harmful because it represents the greater good.
Patients deserve to know these details.
